posts.cooked:
How viable would tracking wheels be for FRC ? I was looking around at FTC and VEX things, and I saw that some teams use two or three undriven Omni wheels with encoders that are pushed onto the ground so that they can use it for odometry ( here’s a website that explains it a bit ) I think this could probably be applied to FRC and would be helpful for detecting when your swerves are slipping and help by adding more data to the pose estimator. Have any teams tried/looked into this, or is it just not very practical or helpful? image 1920×1080 158 KB (credit to FTC team 15173 I think)

image 1920×1080 158 KB

image 1920×1080 158 KB

link_counts.title: How Should Kiwi Drive Localization Kinematics Be?
How to improve accuracy of swerve odometry pose estimation

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
Depends on the game. When there are “bumps” on the field your wheel Odometry will get worse with each pass over the bumps. FTC the fields are so small and the games made in such a way no wire runs are needed on the field. FRC is a bit different and in multiple games we have had rough terrain, wire covers and even a 1 inch metal bar near the endgame areas.

Might be why we don’t see it nearly as much in FRC . It’s still a great idea for situations where you will be on a consistent level floor. With AprilTags maybe you can correct for the bumps now. But prior to their introduction it would’ve been really difficult with the retroflective tape markers.

posts.name: meer
posts.cooked:
Coming from VEX, I thought of the same thing, but to be honest, the better solution for the odometry slip is to combine the swerve pose estimator with a vision to correct the position slips from just the swerve. To add on, VEX / FTC have very different games and very different objectives with their games, in VEX / FTC most of the time, odometry tracking is only used in the auto portion. Meanwhile, in FRC , position tracking is needed for teleop and auto for other subsystems.

It is also really heavily dependent on the game; in Over Under (a 2023-2024 VEX game), many teams had their odometry “pods” but had to lift them up to get over the massive barriers on the field; some teams entirely avoided using the trackers for weight and space.

Dead Wheel Odom is good, but it does slip a lot (in VEX, I saw a team slip a whole foot because they collided with another robot), yes you could have it zero at specific points, but then it’s no better than using just the swerve pose estimator and zeroing. Going over obstacles and getting into collisions will cause it to lose its position fast. It will also take up a good amount of space under your drivetrain and add some unnecessary friction.

For its cost and benefit, using the PhotonVision Pipeline and a good co-processor with a camera might perform even better than the dead wheels with the swerve pose estimator; I might be wrong, though testing is the only way to find out.

1986 used them all the way back in 2017. I’m not sure how helpful odo pods are in FRC however as they can be quite finicky to get right and swerve is much better at not losing traction than mecanum is. In FTC , preventing the pods from slipping is a challenge and often, teams only use them in auto because its hard to keep them accurate for much longer than 30s.

We used them on 842’s bot in 2018 to keep accurate odometry during hard acceleration moves in auto. Results were very good, highly recommended. Spring them hard to the floor so they don’t slip. image 1920×1285 291 KB

image 1920×1285 291 KB

image 1920×1285 291 KB

posts.name: Nic
posts.cooked:
Similarly, the drivetrain meta of each program changes the usefulness of dead wheel odometry pods.

Competitive FTC teams are (almost) always running mecanum, which is difficult to get good wheel odometry out of. Therefore, dead wheel pods are a way to get something usable for autonomous. Similarly, VRC (from what I can tell) likes tank drivetrains of all omni wheels. Like FTC , the drivetrain includes drift/slip as a feature.

This is compared to FRC , where high traction swerve is the norm. Wheel slip is massively less compared to FTC or VRC , so you can get usable wheel odometry from the drive wheels, making separate wheels for odometry has largely irrelevant.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
We tried to make a similar system for 2021 (never got used as we ran out of time to implement the code). We took copper coat hangers and turned them into large springs to keep the Odom pods down to the floor at all times. We had 3 pods, one on each side and one in the rear. As we were using X-Drive it’s closer to Mecanum style wheels and driving. It was designed around the Rev Throughbore hex encoders. As you can see in the picture it wasn’t ever connected to the system for running

posts.name: Troy Dietz
posts.cooked:
Incredibly common in 200 9 due to the irrelevant correlation between drive wheel and robot movement. Mecanum and holonomic drivetrains are the significant beneficiaries now.

Easiest spring mechanism is using a piece of 1/8" polycarbonate as the trailing arm for the wheel.

posts.name: Jefferson
posts.cooked: We played around with it during the at-home challenges in 2021.  We were surprised when we found the nap of the carpet had a tremendous effect on slippage of the omni wheels.  We got about 2X rotations going down the field vs. coming back the other direction.  Side to side seemed to give consistent results. Not something we see on the rubber mats of FTC . It was frustrating enough for us that we bailed on it pretty quickly and went back to swerve odometry.  There may be some particular wheel/arm designs that would have improved our results, but motivations were generally pretty low that year.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
This is such a a fantastic point… I’m so glad we didn’t get far enough then.

Drones have a different method of tracking their distance. Optical Flow Sensors!

This fancy optical flow sensor detects motion of surfaces in front of it, from ~80mm to infinity! It's great for DIY drone builds, and it's compatible with our new Breakout Garden HAT with SPI.

The PMW3901 is a crafty little sensor that uses a low-resolution camera and some clever algorithms to detect motion of surfaces. A great use for it is detecting and correcting for drift of a drone by looking for x/y motion of the ground below.

These are out of stock but the page explains it well. By analyzing the difference in pixels between super fast frames it can estimate X and Y position like an encoder sort of. Ever wonder how a drone is accurate when GPS isn’t down to the mm? When coupled with altimeter data you can know your Z and plot your change in Odom.

Maybe this could be applied to FRC ?

link_counts.title: Laser mice for localization and odemetry?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
kingc95:

Maybe this could be applied to FRC ?

Typically the speeds in FRC are too high versus the surface texture (carpet fibers) for optical flow sensors to keep up.  They need to have a high enough frame rate to actually follow visible elements in the image, so if you move too fast, they won’t be able to do that.  You’d have to do something further away with more texture (e.g. a field border), and at that point, why not use AprilTags, which won’t have false positives versus things like other robot movement?
Could you essentially just take a computer mouse and just put it in the bottom of the robot? Some modern gaming mice have really high polling rates and could potentially be fast enough.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Maybe, but it would have to be almost riding on the field surface, I think?  Which isn’t viable for FRC due to debris and surface roughness.  Maybe a modified mouse with a different focal length, but I would expect the flow rate upper bound to scale with distance from the surface?

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
https://www.sparkfun.com/products/24904 - sparkfun did recently pump out a breakout board using the PAA5160E1 from PixArt. UpACreek’s FTC team apparently used it and had success?

It’s unclear to me how much that board relies on the IMU for localization, versus the optical flow sensor.

Regardless, the optical flow sensor caps out at 8FPS. Not useful for FRC .

The PAT9300E1-QDBB gets closer at 16 FPS, but not quite where FRC would need it (20FPS+).

The fact PixArt advertises their products are used for mobile robotics is cool, but unfortunately FRC is faster paced than roombas.

I do still wonder what a good global-shutter camera pointed downward with good lighting could do. Something something “VIsual Odometery” pipeline coming to photonvision…

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
gerthworm:

The PAT9300E1-QDBB gets closer at 16 FPS, but not quite where FRC would need it (20FPS+).

“working distance of 1.5mm~4.5mm” feels too close for comfort as well.  The PAA5160E1 is much better (10mm to 27mm is about perfect).

gerthworm:

I do still wonder what a good global-shutter camera pointed downward with good lighting could do. Something something “VIsual Odometery” pipeline coming to photonvision…

Some napkin math analysis: As an upper bound, to do optical flow on highly regular (unmarked) carpet you need to track the weave movement; each weave is around 1/4" so you likely need to capture 2-3 frames per quarter inch of movement?  With a robot moving at 20 feet/sec, that means you need (20 ft/sec) * (12 in/ft) * (3 frames / 0.25 in) = 2-3 thousand frames/sec.  This is likely overly conservative because carpet often has variation (marks etc) other than the weave, which would make this a lot more tractable–if the carpet has recognizable (even random smudges would do) markings ~4" apart at most, you’d maybe only need 120-180 frames/sec to do optical flow on those markings.
